data.text:
What is real-time analytics?

Gartner says "Real-time analytics is the discipline that applies logic and mathematics to data to provide insights for making better decisions quickly. For some use cases, real time simply means the analytics is completed within a few seconds or minutes after the arrival of new data."

Real time analytics refers to the process of preparing and measuring data as soon as it enters into the system. In other words, capture live streams of data, process them very quickly, and extract insights or perform operations on the data in real time, which allows businesses to react without delay. They can seize opportunities or prevent problems before they happen. Real-time processing requires a continual input of data, constant processing and steady output of data.

Real-time analytics can be classified into following types:

Streaming Analytics: process the event data on a continuous basis and stream the process result to downstream applications or users in real-time. Example: Online sales trends of specific products for eCommerce company, Forex, stock/share real-time price movements of Bank or investment company, event tracking etc.

On-demand Analytics: Process the event data in real-time and store processed data in a data store or in an application. Users or applications consume processed data on needy a basis from high performing analytical data store. Example: Total web page error messages in last 1 hour, web page visits Vs sale conversation rates since sale launch, Total subscription of an IPO for last 5 hours.

Event Tracking in Real-time Data Analytics

The Event Streaming Data Architecture

The data architecture of event streaming comprises 3 fundamental components

Message Broker: It collects streaming data from so-called producers. Producers can track any event ranging from metrics, clickstreams, searches and etc. All these actions are then stored into the atomic building blocks of the Apache Kafka architecture, namely topics and partitions. One of the key strength of Kafka is its ability to parallelize partitions in order to increase the overall throughput. The information is then made available to consumers which will be using this output in different ways.

*Note: Kafka has been considered as message broker in the following architecture as it is one of the most popular message brokers, and others are Amazon Kenisis, Google Could Pub/Sub, RabbitMQ etc.

ETL Process: The raw data is then transformed and cleaned so that it can be then used by SQL-based systems in order to be analyzed later on.

Data Storage & Analysis: After the data is prepared by our data stream processors we have to store it analyze it in order to provide valuable insights.

Event Tracking Use Case for retail eCommerce

Its been year+ into COVID-19 and it is not ending soon, consumer shopping online has increased significantly across many categories. Consumer intent to shop online continues to increase, especially in essentials and home-entertainment categories. More interestingly, these habits seem like they’re going to stick as prominent consumers reports show an intent to shop online even after the COVID-19 crisis. Categories where expected growth in online shoppers exceeds current trends include essentials such as apparels, groceries, household supplies, and personal-care products. Even discretionary categories such as skin care and makeup, fashion wear, and jewelry and accessories show expected customer growth of more than current percent.

When consumers online presence and spend is increasing, analyzing data over time is valuable, but we’re living in an age where we need to stay on top of trends, make decisions and make them in real-time. With advances in technology and AI, real-time data analytics has become a key contender to business growth and one of the most important facets to any type of business. There’s been a shift in consuming data, and we can now gain critical insights in real-time and consumer behavior as it happens.

Business Operation teams constantly monitoring transactions and activity on its platform to uncover issues and trends in orders, inventory management, and security. Company only will have a very short amount of time in which to identify these situations before the opportunity to respond is lost.

A highly targeted and effective means of granular measurement can be achieved in Event Tracking Analytics through event tracking. The following are the key events which is need to consider in eCommerce business.

The key events aims to describe ecommerce stores should track thru event tracking analytics to measure and understand customer journeys, improve upon them, and ultimately drive more revenue as a result of the granular data that they provide.

Add to Cart Event

Tracking what products are added to the shopping cart provides the ability to analyze not only how many times products are added but also to measure the conversion rate of the product, and comparisons can be drawn with other products against same metric.

Add to Cart Errors

This event will help in analyzing the most common errors that customers encounter when adding items to their shopping carts. Watch out for repeated errors that stand out, so as to ensure that they are taken care of and the user experience is improved upon.

View Product

This event gives insight into what products are most viewed. It can help answer convertion rate and other questions like: Once the products are viewed, what percentage is being added to cart? What percentage is actually bought?

Proceed to Checkout

It is useful to collect checkout traffic data, as it will help with the analysis of the percentage of users that transitioned from checkout to purchase.

Checkout Error

This event helps in tracking errors encountered by shoppers throughout the checkout process.

This is a valuable insight is the ratio of checkout error events to unique checkout error events: the higher the ratio of a specific type of error, the more issues users have with this field (or step) in the checkout process – something certainly worth looking in to and fixing immediately.

Page not Found Errors

This event must be tracked all the time, it helps in alerting IT Ops team and fix it immediately.

The following are some of the use cases of real-time event tracking analytical system.

Conclusion

By using event tracking, eCommerce companies now obtain immediate insight into what consumers are doing on their eCommerce platform. And they can react more quickly and more effectively, making better decisions to maximize returns, than ever.
